I think you are overoptimistic. You still can't get around the social engineering.

It's startling how many otherwise intelligent people have passwords that are 'password', PIN numbers that are '1234', and who, asked nicely, will let total strangers wander into their offices after them because they are assured 'I work here - I left my pass on my desk' or volunteer information over the phone or click on links in emails purporting to be from the IRS or their bank or whoever - no matter how often the IRS or the bank releases bulletins warning that they will never query you by email. 'Hello, I am widow of ex-Nigeria finance minister needing your help' still pulls in suckers.

And if you don't think some of those suckers work in sensitive positions, you're being *really* overoptimistic. The biggest fundamental vulnerability in the cybersecurity system is, to use a rude term, the meatware.

comments.commentBody: If ifs and buts were candy and nuts...

These types of cyber security/hacking stories chronically miss a critical point: the existence of these so-called cyberweapons, as well as the more mundane everyday malware, depend on systemic weaknesses in our computer and network systems, from the operating system to things like DNS. If these fundamental vulnerabilities ever get fixed, most, most if not nearly all, cyber attacks and exploits would disappear overnight.

Teachers and parents on homework!
Teacher viewpoint:
Homework links school with home, and familiarises parents with current focus areas and expectations. It helps give practice in reading and in the things that I've been teaching at school so that the kids can move along faster. Homework needs to be differentiated to suit kids' different levels, and this is time-consuming. Some kids do their homework and so get the practice, and some don't...the ones who don't will need more practice at school. Sometimes it's difficult to know how much help an individual has had from the parent.
Parent viewpoint:
It links school and home and keeps us in touch with current focus areas and expectations. It helps give practice in reading and in things that are being taught at school so that my child can move along faster. It helps me see where my child's strengths and weaknesses lie. Homework is time-consuming, especially if my child doesn't understand something and needs help. I don't know how much help to give. I try to explain things but my child often doesn't understand. I feel that all the homework must be done even though it's obvious that my child still doesn't understand what they're doing.
Bottom line for teachers: Differentiate homework to suit the different levels. Don't introduce new concepts in homework.
Bottom line for parents: Don't do your child's homework. A little guidance or advice is fine.Let the teacher know if they need more than minimal help.

I agree that Facebook can attract narcissists, but it doesn’t mean who all users of this site can be narcissists one day. I use the Facebook primarily as a way to see what is going on with various music groups and other areas that interest me.
I didn't sign up until a year or so ago. But since then, I have been in touch with friends’ childhood and school ships. It is wonderful to see old friends and keep contact with them. The Facebook can be a very useful tool if used carefully otherwise people can spend a lot of time with superficial things. In the recent days people become more shellfishes and this problem is not because of the social networks.

I don't believe that you can measure someone's narcissim by their posts on facebook. Social networks were created as a way of entertainment, to track friends, to chat, post photos of your personal life, etc. However, anyone can stablish boundaries. There is the possibility of protecting your page and sharing your personal stuff only with your good friends. Posting videos in your profile, photos of your last trip, or even songs lyrics don't make you a narcissit person. On the other hand, it  can make you distracted from school or work, because Facebook consumes a person in the most unusual ways and if you don't protect your account, people can find out everything about your life. So, if you want to know more about a fancy restaurant, invite someone to a party or meet new friends, facebook is the perfect social network, but you must be careful and assure that it won't turn into an addiction.

The "market" is being structured to drive independent and solo practicioners out of "business" Capitation, low fee structures. Read the report of the New York State Finance Department released earlier this year that exposed the games the insurance companies are playing to shift more of the cost to the patient...to the patient's surprise. Now that the UCF (usual and customary fees) can no longer be fiddled; the insurance companies are shiftint the fee basis to 140% of the Medicare fee. Sounds good doesn't it: 80% of the UCF vs 140% of the Medicare fee... but the Medicare fee is so low that at 140% the payment is almost half of the fee under the 80% UCF.
Face it, you can't afford your medical care, your life and health are only of unlimited value to you not your insurer, and you'll get what you can afford. ACA just rearranged the deck chairs on the Titanic.

As the bundling of reimbursement of physician services continues by both medicare and commercial insurers, you will see more of the large multi-specialty practice model become prevalent.  This is all about the money.  These entities (mostly owned by hospital corporations) are very profit driven and limit physicians' ability to practice independently.  Under this practice model, physicians are not judged by how good of a doctor they are in the eyes of the patients, but rather how well they accomplish arbitrary and often inane criteria that ultimately result in better profits for the company.  The ACA and the resultant regulations that came about from the ACA is promoting this trend.  The field of primary care is going to be degraded because of this.  Physicians as employees of a corporation cannot function as doctors with the many other pressures to fulfill other non-clinical obligations.

Even Nixon strategist Kevin Phillips, author of The Emerging Republican Majority (1969), predicted a liberal renaissance in 1990 in his book The Politics of Rich and Poor.

And in 2008 a liberal presidential candidate inspired passion unseen since Bobby Kennedy's campaign of 40 years earlier.
What happened to the promise?

Well, there's the recalcitrance of a Republican house in what is has become surely the world's most gridlocked governmental system where 60 per cent is required for the most routine vote.

But there is also a liberal cowardice in dealing with two realities: program spending as a percent of gdp, and taxes as a percent of gdp. To maintain an activist government requires tax revenue. Othewise unsustainable deficits arise.

But the North American liberals are spooked by tax realities, and lack the leadership and courage to talk about taxes.
Even in Canada, a far more liberal state, tax fear under Liberal governments led to an erosion of program spending from 20 per cent of gdp in the 80s to 14 per cent, and our current neoconservatives are going lower.

Governments that have raised taxes, and have explained why they have raised taxes, get re-elected. None other than Ronald Reagan performed that trick.

But no current liberal politicians have the courage. And without the requisite tax revenues, all the program proposals come to nought, and Grover Norquist reigns.

Somebody has to say the Clinton tax rates need to be restored, and not just on high incomes.

"There is a price for everything" really is a very simplistic thing to say.

Just my two cents.

Maureen's column was very illuminating; I suspect that this cautious and thoughtful man probably has done all he was ever going to be able to accomplish, which is not insignificant by any means.  President Obama showed us that we can elect any president who shows compelling merit, regardless of race or soon I suspect, gender.  He started health care reform.  He rescued the auto industry.  He swept us from the precipice of economic catastrophe.  He showed us that it was possible to dream of an entirely new America.  I am utterly satisfied with these accomplishments, even while grasping the unhappy thought that apparently he is not the right person to take on the craven interests that pit his demise. Given the opportunity, this Republican economy and its perpetrators with Mitt in charge in 2013 eventually will create such a lasting and epic catastrophe that no citizen in his or her right mind will ever be persuaded to vote these or any of their ilk into high office again.  Watch what happens in Europe over the next 12 months if you want a preview of things to happen here.

It is a huge problem, and it is doing enormous damage to democracy. Any little bit helps. But this would only be a little bit of help.

So do it, but don't sit back. We need some huge changes that will be hard fought by those who gain by this abuse.

Those who gain by this abuse have abused it enough to become deeply entrenched, and it will only get harder as time passes.

I still say our economy is closer to 1928 or 1929 than 1937. By 1937, the economy had undergone robust growth in 1933 and 1934 and 1935 and 1936. We have seen no such growth in the "recovery" since the 2008/2009 recession. We have had stagnant growth, stagnant wages, little improvement in unemployment, but we still have the massive income disparity which defined the 1920s.

Unless and until we do something about income disparity, we will continue to have a weak economy.
